Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: 3D Printed Vapor Cooled Liquid Hydrogen Storage Tank for Use in Enterprise Level Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase I project will develop 3D printed liquid hydrogen fuel tanks for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). UAVs are currently powered by long endurance low reliability gasoline engines, or short endurance highly reliable electric propulsion. Hydrogen fuel cells offer the potential for long endurance highly reliable propulsion if the proper hydrogen storage method is used. Through the innovative hydrogen storage system developed by this project, fuel cell electric vehicles can advance national health and welfare through reduction of emissions, and promotion of energy independence both on the ground and in the air. This project will develop a new class of liquid hydrogen storage tanks for electric UAVs that will increase the reliability and performance of surveillance platforms in the armed forces, reducing risk to American service personnel while they secure the defense of our nation. The same electric platforms will promote the national welfare by enabling the inspection of key energy and transportation infrastructure and serving as intelligence and communications platforms for first responders during natural disasters. In addition, the key technology developed in this project will expand the utility of additive manufacturing by demonstrating the capabilities and performance of engineered plastics in cryogenic (< -238°F) environments. Such cryogenic rated 3D printed polymer parts have wide ranging impacts, including cost reduction, across cryogenic dependent technology areas from medical devices and spacecraft to drug and food processing.

Additively manufactured polymers have never been used in cryogenic applications until now. The correct selection of polymer blend, testing and selection of a lightweight impermeable membrane, and thermal characterization of novel insulation materials are critical to project success. Since most cryogenic research, such as -423°F permeation of hydrogen through polymers, has not been studied since the 1960s, extensive cryogenic engineering and testing experience is required to apply modern materials and manufacturing methods to the project. The objectives of this project will fill knowledge gaps by testing metallized polymer films for hydrogen permeability, as well as manufacturing methods to cost effectively apply it to insulation panels or tank walls. While prior research has identified a polymer blend that is robust to cryogenic thermal cycling, the possibility of microcracking has not yet been thoroughly addressed and will be evaluated in this project. Novel insulation materials never before used in commercial cryogenic applications will be thermally characterized and integrated into the prototype tank. This project will conclude by completing a liquid hydrogen fuel fill and measuring the mass boil-off rate to test computational fluid dynamic modeled performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective for the Phase I project was to build a small (5 L) liquid hydrogen storage tank (VCS tank) for a fuel cell powered unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). Protium Innovation?s unique approach uses additive manufacturing that incorporates vapor cooled channels into the tank walls to reduce heat load into the liquid hydrogen, while warming the cold hydrogen vapor to near ambient temperature. Integrating the heat exchanger into the tank eliminates the need for a stand-alone unit, which would otherwise reduce key performance metrics such as gravimetric capacity (total percentage of the fueling system mass that is hydrogen) and specific energy (energy contained in the hydrogen divided by the total mass of the tank and hydrogen) of the storage system. We use selective laser sintering (SLS) of a polymer blend to create the complex geometry necessary, along with novel insulation materials, to achieve the required heat load that maintains a boil-off rate sufficient for average cruise velocity of the UAV. Power requirements above that necessary for average cruise use a heater in the tank to increase the boil-off rate.


By using low density polymers in lieu of metal, additional mass reduction is possible due to the low pressure of liquid hydrogen storage tanks (~30 psig) that do not require the higher tensile strength of metals. The low thermal conductivity of polymers, 20x less than stainless steel and 200x less than aluminum at 20 K, provides an added benefit in terms of increased thermal performance. This innovation is designed to provide 8+ hours of reliable, quiet, and low maintenance electric fuel cell propulsion for a 25 kg UAV.


Intellectual Merit
The specific goals for the Phase I STTR assessed: 1) the thermal performance of a novel insulation material at cryogenic temperatures; 2) the hydrogen permeation rate of metalized and non-metalized polymer films at cryogenic temperatures; 3) methods for laminating the insulating foam with the polymer films; 4) thermal performance of the tank; and 5) assessment of micro-cracking in polymer shells.


1)    Silica aerogel based insulation materials are considered the state-of-the-art for high and low temperature applications. A new foamed insulation made from polyimide was tested down to 40 K to compare the thermal conductivity to aerogel insulations and to the thermal conductivity of the polymer the tank is printed from. At higher temperatures (160 K) the polyimide based insulation outperformed the polymer shell material by 0.5X - 2X but showed no difference in thermal conductivity at 45 K. Silica aerogel based insulation outperformed the new polyimide based insulation at all temperatures and therefore remains preferable for use in cryogenic applications.


2)    Our study showed the lowest leak rate obtainable was through uncoated 3D printed material supported by a plate. Printed samples that were coated with aluminum had higher rates of permeation which could be attributable to print quality and degree of particle fusion during the laser sintering process. Further research is required to determine the cause of these counter intuitive results.


3)    Laminating aerogel based insulation materials with aluminized film along complex contours resulted in poor fit. Custom molds could be built to achieve better form but such an approach is cost prohibitive for small production runs. An alternative that we tested was to coat the polymer material with aluminum such as Mylar film is produced. This approach yields a uniform permeation barrier directly on the tank shell material that is cost effective and eliminates manufacturing difficulties.


4)    Thermal performance of the tank when tested with liquid nitrogen showed close agreement with computational fluid dynamic models thus validating the design methodology.


5)    The formation of micro-cracks and subsequent failure in polymers exposed to repeated cryogenic thermal cycles is of significant concern. Our tests indicated minimal degradation in ultimate strength or elastic modulus in samples that had been cycled 200 times to 77 K. These results indicate certain polymer blends used in additive manufacturing are suitable for use in cryogenic environments.


Broader Impact
The specific goal of this research is to develop next generation liquid hydrogen fueling systems for fuel cell powered UAVs. Electric propulsion is more reliable, less polluting, and quieter than propulsion systems powered by internal combustion engines. Batteries are typically used for electrical energy storage but are heavy and can only offer flight times of around 2 hours. Fuel cells and liquid hydrogen can provide flight times 5x - 10x longer.

The results of this research extend the unique capabilities of 3D printed polymers into other fields that rely on or encounter cryogenic temperatures such as space craft, medical devices, and food processing. Many spacecraft use composite polymers for structural isolation of temperature sensitive instruments from heat sources. The advantages that 3D printing offers through development of complex shapes that would other wise be cost prohibitive or impossible to manufacture opens up new dimensions to engineering solutions.



Last Modified: 03/18/2019
Modified by: Patrick M Adam

Integrating the heat exchanger into the tank eliminates the need for a stand-alone unit, which would otherwise reduce key performance metrics such as gravimetric capacity (total percentage of the fueling system mass that is hydrogen) and specific energy (energy contained in the hydrogen divided by the total mass of the tank and hydrogen) of the storage system.
